title: Don’t Adjust the Brightness: Here’s Why TV and Movies Are So Dark Now
excerpt: While dark scenes are usually due to the filmmaker’s vision, there are several factors both at movie theaters and when viewing at home that will affect the viewer’s ability to see what’s going on onscreen.

content.text:
Have you ever been enjoying a film or TV series, only to suddenly find yourself squinting at the dark screen? Recent releases including “
Euphoria
,” “The Batman” and “Handmaid’s Tale,” as well as classic films including ��Alien,” “Taxi Driver” and “Seven” all utilize dark imagery, but what if the visuals are simply too dark to see everything in the frame?
While dark scenes are usually due to the filmmaker’s vision, there are several factors both at movie theaters and when viewing at home that will affect the viewer’s ability to see what’s going on onscreen.
Home viewing
For home viewers, one culprit could be the viewing environment, according to digital imaging technician Nicholas Kay. When he goes to visit his parents’ house, he’s aghast at the butchered image quality on their television screen, which Kay believes should be as neutral as possible. As someone who spends countless hours perfecting visuals on- and off-set, he feels personally offended by the settings on his parents’ TV, from 
motion smoothing
 to brightness, which Kay said shouldn’t be turned up or down.
“They watch this stuff, and I’m like, ‘Oh my God, you’re killing me, like please, let me help you,’” Kay said. “And then I help them, and they’re like, ‘Oh, what happened?’ I’m like, ‘What do you mean, what happened? This is how you’re supposed to see it!’”
The settings on a TV are just one factor when it comes to how a film is ultimately viewed. Other determinants might be the lighting in the room or the size and quality of the monitor.
Images in movie theaters, which should provide the ultimate viewing experience for cinephiles, can be just as dark as a badly adjusted home screen. Many projectors are not 
well maintained
 and even 4K resolution can fall flat.


When the final season of “Game of Thrones” aired in 2019, many viewers said they couldn’t see what was going on during battle sequences.
But ultimately, the reason a movie or series seems super dark is that it’s how the filmmaker intended it to look.
A few years ago, a final battle in the “Game of Thrones” finale was criticized by many viewers for being so dark that it was impossible to see what was going on. Cinematographer Fabian Wagner 
defended his work
 at the time, telling Wired, “Everything we wanted people to see is there.” He also pointed out that the scene was shot at night and said the intention was to differentiate the battle aesthetically from other scenes throughout the series. He also stressed that watching the show anywhere other than a darkened room with a neutral, large monitor was a disservice to the viewer.
Mood-setter
Other than the viewing environment, though, Kay, a two-decade industry vet who has worked on movies including “Joker,” “Venom” and “Black Panther,” said there are practical and emotional reasons for dark images. Whether “dark” refers to the moodiness of a piece of media or its literal lack of light, the two often go hand-in-hand.
Matt Reeves’ “The Batman” takes place largely at night, “The Handmaid’s Tale” is set in a gloomy dystopia, and horror movies like the “Fear Street” trilogy rely on the cover of darkness to keep viewers on their toes. Those works and more have all faced criticism for being too shadowy (the 
West Wind Drive-In in Las Vegas
 told patrons that they couldn’t get a refund for “The Batman” if they found it too dark) but the alternative might be an unrealistic depiction of the plot.
“I think that a lot of cinematographers, when they do certain things like that, they’re trying to make it feel extremely truthful,” Kay said. “I don’t think the intention is to struggle to see, but there are times where I personally feel like I’m struggling, like, ‘Is it taking me out of it?’ My job really is to calibrate my eye to what the cinematographer wants it to look like.”


Of course, it’s not just newer titles that have viewers straining their eyes. Over the years, films from “Alien” (1979) to the aptly titled “Dark City” (1998), have been presented with extremely dark images. One difference, Kay says, is that those movies were shot on film, while most modern cinema is shot digitally. Even the digital remasters of those classic films might appear much flatter than the original, because 35mm film has two to three times more grains per square inch than 4K has in pixels. That means cinematographers have to get creative when it comes to crafting a unique and “organic” image.
“What they’re fighting is the sharpness and the crispness and the perfection of digital,” Kay said. “That’s what they would all say, and that’s why they want to shoot on film or that’s why they want to use a lot of smoke and filters — to basically take away the perfection.”
‘Euphoria’s’ Special Treatment
One of the most notable deviations from the digital landscape is Sam Levinson’s HBO teen drama “Euphoria.” The show’s second season was shot on 35mm Kodak Ektachrome, which forced Kodak to convert part of its factory to produce the discontinued film stock.
“Euphoria” has become well-known for its unique visuals, and cinematographer Marcell Rév said the stock’s film speed of 100 ISO (the metric for how much light the film picks up) forced them to light the set “like we were lighting a sitcom.” The result is an extremely textured final image that allows Rév to play with light in ways most filmmakers can’t, and he acknowledged that contrast is an important aspect of his vision.
“We were trying to do like velvety deep shadows, but I don’t think they are dark,” Rév said.” You always have very bright reference points in every image. I don’t think there are images where you’re wondering what’s on the image.”


Rév said he doesn’t believe that films are trending darker or lighter in general, but noted one inspiration in the world of film noir: 
David Fincher
 — specifically his 1995 film “Seven.”
“It’s a really dark [film],” Rév said. “That revolutionized the way they shot movies in the ‘90s, the way that [cinematographer] Darius Khondji used film stock and how he underexposed film stock and how he lit that movie. It was something so original and unique. It was in the ‘90s and it was way darker than anything I can see now in the cinema.”
In “The Batman,” Reeves and cinematographer Greig Fraser 
employed a technique
 similar to Khondji’s, where they printed the digital print of the movie onto film and used a bleach bypass to achieve a more high-contrast image. The 
technique
 marries aspects of film and digital, and creates a more textured look than most digitally shot superhero movies would allow.
As a technician who entered the industry as it was transitioning from film to digital, Kay’s job, he said, is often to help directors and cinematographers capture the essence of the films they grew up watching, trying to emulate the look and feel of film without any special treatment from Kodak.
Kay said that ever since digital has taken hold, studios have also gained more control when it comes to the final product. As a result, he said he believes many films are actually brighter than they need to be, with the exception being the works of well-known auteurs and cinematographers who have full control of the resolution and coloring of their movies. He referenced the work of his friend, cinematographer 
Bradford Young
, who has shot films including “Solo: A Star Wars Story” (2018), “Arrival” (2015) and the 2019 mini-series “When They See Us,” which Kay also worked on. Those works all utilize dark imagery, but Kay said that’s entirely on purpose.
“He likes things darker, as an example of people who like to be more honest with the image, and certain scenarios and scenes are dark,” Kay said. “‘When They See Us,’ I know, was dark and smoky, but it was meant to be this organic, visceral experience where these kids are suffering.”


Lighting darker skin tones can also lead to problems for cinematographers, and the industry has only 
recently
 begun to acknowledge the inequity faced by Black actors and other people of color on screen. Many of the 
technologies
 used for lighting have been historically calibrated for white people, which is why the work of cinematographers like Young and 
Ava Berkofsky
 on “Insecure” has contributed so much to the craft.
In terms of his work on “Joker” (2019), photographed by Lawrence Sher, and “Venom” (2018), photographed by Matthew Libatique, Kay said the dark visuals were justified.


“‘Joker’ wasn’t even that dark to me,” Kay said. “It was more dark in theme. I don’t feel like you’re struggling to see it. It’s more like it takes place at night a lot of times or on subways or things like that. You know, the lights are going on and off … It’s all practically motivated.”
Beyond aesthetic or practical motivation, though, sometimes the reason for a scene’s dark lighting is much more mundane. If a movie utilizes special effects makeup or if a shot picks up lighting cables in the background, the darkness provides a great solution for hiding things that filmmakers don’t want the audience to notice. The modern techniques of CGI and VFX editing can fix the issue, but for lower budget projects, the old-school way is often much easier.
“‘Just paint it black’ is literally the answer to everything,” Kay said. “‘Alien’ is a great example of hiding things like prosthetics, all that kind of stuff. Those prosthetics look real, because they’re in a real environment and they’re lit realistically. To light them more, you start to reveal that they’re fake.”
Adjust Your TV
But, regardless of why an image seems dim, Kay has a few tips for making sure you have the best shot at seeing a film the way it was intended. He suggested Googling the make and model of your TV set to learn how to neutralize the settings, adding, “If a window outside is pointing at your screen, you’re fighting an uphill battle.”
When it comes to your 
local movie theater
, keep an eye out for smudged screens or washed-out picture quality, and alert the theater manager. Make a point of patronizing cinemas that prioritize the viewer experience, such as AMC’s Dolby Cinemas or Alamo Drafthouse.
When it comes to lack of control over how someone will watch one of the projects on which he spends months perfecting the imagery, Kay takes the challenges of his work in stride.
“Most people are gonna be watching this on an airplane or an iPhone anyway,” Kay said, “but that doesn’t stop you from trying.”

Matt Reeves’ “The Batman” takes place largely at night, “The Handmaid’s Tale” is set in a gloomy dystopia, and horror movies like the “Fear Street” trilogy rely on the cover of darkness to keep viewers on their toes. Those works and more have all faced criticism for being too shadowy (the
West Wind Drive-In in Las Vegas
told patrons that they couldn’t get a refund for “The Batman” if they found it too dark) but the alternative might be an unrealistic depiction of the plot.

“I think that a lot of cinematographers, when they do certain things like that, they’re trying to make it feel extremely truthful,” Kay said. “I don’t think the intention is to struggle to see, but there are times where I personally feel like I’m struggling, like, ‘Is it taking me out of it?’ My job really is to calibrate my eye to what the cinematographer wants it to look like.”

Of course, it’s not just newer titles that have viewers straining their eyes. Over the years, films from “Alien” (1979) to the aptly titled “Dark City” (1998), have been presented with extremely dark images. One difference, Kay says, is that those movies were shot on film, while most modern cinema is shot digitally. Even the digital remasters of those classic films might appear much flatter than the original, because 35mm film has two to three times more grains per square inch than 4K has in pixels. That means cinematographers have to get creative when it comes to crafting a unique and “organic” image.

“What they’re fighting is the sharpness and the crispness and the perfection of digital,” Kay said. “That’s what they would all say, and that’s why they want to shoot on film or that’s why they want to use a lot of smoke and filters — to basically take away the perfection.”

One of the most notable deviations from the digital landscape is Sam Levinson’s HBO teen drama “Euphoria.” The show’s second season was shot on 35mm Kodak Ektachrome, which forced Kodak to convert part of its factory to produce the discontinued film stock.

“Euphoria” has become well-known for its unique visuals, and cinematographer Marcell Rév said the stock’s film speed of 100 ISO (the metric for how much light the film picks up) forced them to light the set “like we were lighting a sitcom.” The result is an extremely textured final image that allows Rév to play with light in ways most filmmakers can’t, and he acknowledged that contrast is an important aspect of his vision.

“We were trying to do like velvety deep shadows, but I don’t think they are dark,” Rév said.” You always have very bright reference points in every image. I don’t think there are images where you’re wondering what’s on the image.”
Rév said he doesn’t believe that films are trending darker or lighter in general, but noted one inspiration in the world of film noir:

“It’s a really dark [film],” Rév said. “That revolutionized the way they shot movies in the ‘90s, the way that [cinematographer] Darius Khondji used film stock and how he underexposed film stock and how he lit that movie. It was something so original and unique. It was in the ‘90s and it was way darker than anything I can see now in the cinema.”
In “The Batman,” Reeves and cinematographer Greig Fraser
similar to Khondji’s, where they printed the digital print of the movie onto film and used a bleach bypass to achieve a more high-contrast image. The
marries aspects of film and digital, and creates a more textured look than most digitally shot superhero movies would allow.

As a technician who entered the industry as it was transitioning from film to digital, Kay’s job, he said, is often to help directors and cinematographers capture the essence of the films they grew up watching, trying to emulate the look and feel of film without any special treatment from Kodak.

Kay said that ever since digital has taken hold, studios have also gained more control when it comes to the final product. As a result, he said he believes many films are actually brighter than they need to be, with the exception being the works of well-known auteurs and cinematographers who have full control of the resolution and coloring of their movies. He referenced the work of his friend, cinematographer

, who has shot films including “Solo: A Star Wars Story” (2018), “Arrival” (2015) and the 2019 mini-series “When They See Us,” which Kay also worked on. Those works all utilize dark imagery, but Kay said that’s entirely on purpose.

“He likes things darker, as an example of people who like to be more honest with the image, and certain scenarios and scenes are dark,” Kay said. “‘When They See Us,’ I know, was dark and smoky, but it was meant to be this organic, visceral experience where these kids are suffering.”
Lighting darker skin tones can also lead to problems for cinematographers, and the industry has only
begun to acknowledge the inequity faced by Black actors and other people of color on screen. Many of the
used for lighting have been historically calibrated for white people, which is why the work of cinematographers like Young and
on “Insecure” has contributed so much to the craft.
In terms of his work on “Joker” (2019), photographed by Lawrence Sher, and “Venom” (2018), photographed by Matthew Libatique, Kay said the dark visuals were justified.

“‘Joker’ wasn’t even that dark to me,” Kay said. “It was more dark in theme. I don’t feel like you’re struggling to see it. It’s more like it takes place at night a lot of times or on subways or things like that. You know, the lights are going on and off … It’s all practically motivated.”

Beyond aesthetic or practical motivation, though, sometimes the reason for a scene’s dark lighting is much more mundane. If a movie utilizes special effects makeup or if a shot picks up lighting cables in the background, the darkness provides a great solution for hiding things that filmmakers don’t want the audience to notice. The modern techniques of CGI and VFX editing can fix the issue, but for lower budget projects, the old-school way is often much easier.

“‘Just paint it black’ is literally the answer to everything,” Kay said. “‘Alien’ is a great example of hiding things like prosthetics, all that kind of stuff. Those prosthetics look real, because they’re in a real environment and they’re lit realistically. To light them more, you start to reveal that they’re fake.”

But, regardless of why an image seems dim, Kay has a few tips for making sure you have the best shot at seeing a film the way it was intended. He suggested Googling the make and model of your TV set to learn how to neutralize the settings, adding, “If a window outside is pointing at your screen, you’re fighting an uphill battle.”

, keep an eye out for smudged screens or washed-out picture quality, and alert the theater manager. Make a point of patronizing cinemas that prioritize the viewer experience, such as AMC’s Dolby Cinemas or Alamo Drafthouse.
When it comes to lack of control over how someone will watch one of the projects on which he spends months perfecting the imagery, Kay takes the challenges of his work in stride.
“Most people are gonna be watching this on an airplane or an iPhone anyway,” Kay said, “but that doesn’t stop you from trying.”

title: EXCLUSIVE: After SS Rajamouli, Chiranjeevi comes on board Ranbir Kapoor & Alia Bhatt's Brahmastra - Details
excerpt: The first theatrical trailer of Ranbir Kapoor, and Alia Bhatt fronted Brahmastra will be launched on June 15. The action adventure also features Amitabh Bachchan, Dimple Kapadia, Nagarjuna and Mouni Roy in key roles.

content.text:
The Ayan Mukerji directed Brahmastra, fronted by Ranbir Kapoor and Alia Bhatt with Amitabh Bachchan, Nagarjuna, Dimple Kapadia and Mouni Roy is among the most awaited films of the year. As the makers gear up to launch the theatrical trailer of the film on June 15, we have got a big update on this mythological action adventure. According to our sources, team Brahmastra is planning a big association with Megastar Chiranjeevi and the announcement is round the corner.
"Brahmastra is a Pan India product coming out of the Hindi Film Industry and the team is leaving no stone unturned to tap the true potential of the Indian market. While SS Rajamouli is presenting the film in the 4 South  Indian Languages, the talks are on with Chiranjeevi for some special association," revealed a source, adding further that the role of involvement will be announced once all the things are finalized. 

"Ayan recently flew down to Hyderabad  to have a special meeting with Chiranjeevi and it went off well. While no one is aware of the intricate details, there is something brewing between Ayan, Chiranjeevi and the entire Brahmastra team," the source added.  The action adventure is produced by Star Studios with Karan Johar and is gearing up for a September 9 release.


A prolonged marketing campaign has been planned for Brahmastra, wherein the makers will continue to unveil various facets of the film to keep the intrigue and conversation intact. It's the costliest film to come out of Bollywood and the eyes are now on the big day of trailer launch, as the team will introduce to the audience to the world of Ayan's labour of love on June 15. Stay tuned to Pinkvilla for more updates on Brahmastra.

title: Munawar Faruqui's Second Marriage: A Secret Union with Mehzabeen Coatwala
excerpt: Comedian and Bigg Boss 17 winner Munawar Faruqui has reportedly married makeup artist Mehzabeen Coatwala in a private ceremony. The secret wedding, held at ITC Grand Central, has left fans curious and eager for details. This new chapter in Munawar's life follows his tumultuous first marriage and public controversies. As the comedian steps into this new relationship, the media and his followers are eagerly awaiting more information.

content.text:
Munawar Faruqui Starts a New Chapter with Secret Wedding to Mehzabeen Coatwala
Comedian and Bigg Boss 17 winner Munawar Faruqui surprised fans with the news of his second marriage to makeup artist Mehzabeen Coatwala. The private ceremony, shrouded in secrecy, took place around 10-12 days ago at the ITC Grand Central. A leaked photo without Munawar has fueled curiosity about the event.
Who is Mehzabeen Coatwala?


Mehzabeen Coatwala, a professional makeup artist, has been thrust into the spotlight due to her marriage to Munawar. Although not much is publicly known about her, interest in her background and relationship with the comedian continues to grow.
Munawar's Journey of Love and Loss


This is Munawar's second marriage. His previous relationship ended amidst controversy, marked by allegations of infidelity and public disputes. The comedian openly discussed the challenges of his first marriage and his struggles as a father during his appearances on reality shows like "Lock Upp" and "Bigg Boss 17."
Public and Media Reactions
News of the secret wedding sparked a frenzy on social media, with fans expressing surprise and sending their best wishes. While Munawar has yet to comment publicly, the media and his followers are eager for confirmation and more details.  His ability to keep such a major life event private speaks to his desire for privacy amidst his fame.
A New Chapter


As Munawar begins this new chapter with Mehzabeen, fans are curious about how the marriage will impact his personal and professional life. Known for his resilience and openness, Munawar continues to captivate audiences on and off the stage.
Stay Tuned for Updates
Stay connected for the latest news and updates on Munawar Faruqui and his new marriage as the story unfolds.

title: Kirsten Dunst Teases Possible Spider-Man Return After Tobey Maguire's Comeback
excerpt: In the year leading up to Spider-Man: No Way Home, the question was always whether Andrew Garfield and Tobey Maguire would appear alongside Tom Holland.

content.text:
In the year leading up to 
Spider-Man: No Way Home
, the question was always whether 
Andrew Garfield and Tobey Maguire would appear
 alongside Tom Holland. In fact, that question did more for the threequel than its marketing department ever could. But almost immediately upon the film's theatrical release, fans began asking a new question: Will Sony 
revive Tobey and Andrew's respective Spider-Man franchises
?
While Sony has yet to confirm a Tobey Maguire 
Spider-Man 4 
or 
Andrew Garfield's 
The Amazing Spider-Man 3
, both former web-slingers have now expressed their own willingness to continue playing the Marvel hero. This is even something Marvel and Sony's current 
Spider-Man, Tom Holland, has expressed his support
 for. 
However, if Sony were to return to their worlds, what about their supporting casts? After all, 
Maguire's Peter Parker confirmed Kirsten Dunst's Mary-Jane
 is still in the picture. Would the newly Oscar-nominated Dunst want to return if cinema's original Spidey has more story to tell? 
Kirsten Dunst Hints at Mary Jane's Spider-Man Return


In an interview with 
Deadline
, Kirsten Dunst, who played Mary Jane Watson in Tobey Maguire's 
Spider-Man
 trilogy, teased that 
"there's still time" 
for her to return to the role. 
When asked if she would've liked to have reprised her character of Mary Jane alongside Tobey Maguire's Peter Parker in 
Spider-Man: No Way Home
, the actress kept the option open for this to happen:
"There's still time. I mean, listen, no one's asked me about anything, but I do think that, I mean, this Multi Universe keeps going on and on so I feel like that could happen. I know nothing, by the way."
When asked in previous interviews if she would be open to returning to the role, 
Dunst actually called it a 
"no-brainer"
 and credited the original 
Spider-Man
 films for the positive impact that they had on her life and career. 
Dunst first appeared as Peter Parker's love interest and aspiring actress in 2002's 
Spider-Man,
 directed by Sam Raimi. She then continued to play opposite Maguire's Peter Parker in 
Spider-Man 2 
and 
Spider-Man 3
; however, the third film of Raimi's trilogy left the couple on somewhat shaky terms. 
In fact, their 
"complicated"
 relationship was something 
Maguire's Parker alluded to in 
No Way Home
 while, at the same time, acknowledging that the two
 "made it work." 
Amid the web of 
rumors leading up to 
Spider-Man: No Way Home
's release, there was speculation that Dunst would appear as Mary Jane. 
Dunst denied the rumors
 and was proven to be correct; however, given the odds of another Maguire comeback, she's likely to get more Spider-Man questions now than she did before. 
Mary Jane 
Parker
 in Spider-Man 4?
"This, like any story worth telling, is all about a girl. That girl. The girl next door. Mary Jane Watson." 
Unlike Tom Holland's Spider-Man, and in some ways, even Andrew Garfield's, Tobey Maguire's Spider-Man story was always driven by his pursuit of Kirsten Dunst's Mary-Jane Watson. 
If Maguire has a new future as the web-slinger in anything besides a cameo, Dunst's Mary-Jane would need to be involved; and the fact that she's so willing has to be great news for Sony and/or Marvel. 
However, her interest - and studio plans for a Maguire film - may have been confirmed long before 
No Way Home
. After all, Maguire's Peter Parker's words about Mary-Jane and their relationship were chosen for a reason; and while they 
"made it work,"
 the fact that it's still
 "complicated"
 felt open-ended and as if there's more story to tell. 
Now, since both 
Dunst and Maguire's former director Sam Raimi
 is at the helm of 
Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness
, there are
 rumors suggesting Maguire's web-slinger may make an appearance
. It's also a rumor that makes sense given the sequel picks up after the events of 
No Way Home
 and involves parallel universes and variants. 
If so, it's also possible that Dunst could cameo as well, especially given her eagerness to return to the character and 
Multiverse of Madness
' substantial reshoots
. 
Regardless, given 
the success of
 No Way Home
 and the fan appetite for more of Garfield and Maguire's Spider-
Men
, whether audiences see more of the prior Spideys - and their casts - doesn't seem to be a question of if, but when.  
Spider-Man: No Way Home 
is still playing in theaters but will be available for purchase digitally on March 22, 2022. Its physical media release will come on April 12, 2022.

title: Apex Legends streamer hits jaw-dropping backflip to counter Kraber
excerpt: Apex streamer Jankz stunned viewers after hitting a ridiculous backflip dodge over a Kraber bullet in a duos game on World’s Edge.

content.text:
Apex streamer Jankz stunned viewers after hitting a ridiculous backflip dodge over a Kraber bullet in a duos game on World’s Edge. 
The Kraber is one of the most deadly weapons in all of Apex Legends. Thanks to its 3x damage multiplier for headshots, it is the only gun in the game that can eliminate a player with a single shot.
That’s what makes this dodge from 
Jankz
 such a stunning play, as he baits an enemy into shooting at him just to unveil that he was ready for the aggression all along.
Jankz hits unbelievable backflip to dodge a Kraber in Apex Legends


The stage was set for this moment when the streamer and his duo  chased a team into a building after the duo spotted an empty care package.
After a moment of fighting, Jankz gets hit with a Kraber bullet and calls it out to let his friend know what’s going on. More fighting ensues and the duo collects a knock on Octane before preparing to push the opposing sniper.
After a brief standoff at a closed door, Jankz anticipates the opposing Wattson’s next move and lands a perfectly timed backflip to avoid the incoming bullet.



There were a number of stunned reactions, but one user commented that it was only right for Jankz to pull this off given his history of making ridiculous plays: “Watched the Jankz V.O.D. yesterday and nearly dropped my phone. The dude is just so much fun to watch."
While everyone else was busy being astounded by this clip, one commenter slipped in a not-so-subtle joke about the ongoing aim-assist debate in the higher tiers of Apex: “Damn controller players and their backflip assist.”
This isn’t the kind of feat that can be recreated in every fight vs a Kraber but it is a handy tool to have in your arsenal if you find yourself in one of these close-range fights vs. the one-shot king.

title: Check out luxurious car collection of Bigg Boss 15 winner Tejasswi Prakash
excerpt: Check out luxurious car collection of Bigg Boss 15 winner Tejasswi Prakash

content.text:
Tejasswi Prakash is riding high due to her Bigg Boss 15 win currently. She has recently won the reality show and also at the same time grabbed the lead actress role of Naagin 6. The actress has all the reasons to be happy. Well, even her love life is also in news. She has been dating Karan Kundrra and the duo is very open about their relationship. They had fallen for each other on Bigg Boss 15. 
Well, Tejasswi began her acting career with Sanskaar - Dharohar Apnon Ki. She played Dhara’s role. Following this, she portrayed the lead role of Ragini Gadodia in Colors TV's Swaragini - Jodein Rishton Ke Sur opposite Namish Taneja. Then the actress was seen in Sony TV's Pehredaar Piya Ki opposite Affan Khan. After Pehredaar Piya Ki ended, Prakash was re-cast as Diya Singh in Rishta Likhenge Hum Naya opposite Rohit Suchanti. She has also been part of Karn Sangini opposite Aashim Gulati.
She has also participated in Colors TV's Fear Factor: Khatron Ke Khiladi 10. Apart from this the actress also owns an expensive car. She is a proud owner of the Red color Hyundai i-20 car.
Take a look here:


The Hyundai i20 starts at Rs 6.79 lakh (ex-showroom) and goes up to Rs 11.17 lakh (ex-showroom). The petrol variant ranges between Rs 6.79 lakh - Rs 9.69 lakh (ex-showroom). The diesel variant ranges between Rs 8.19 lakh - Rs 10.59 lakh (ex-showroom).

Then the actress was seen in Sony TV's Pehredaar Piya Ki opposite Affan Khan. After Pehredaar Piya Ki ended, Prakash was re-cast as Diya Singh in Rishta Likhenge Hum Naya opposite Rohit Suchanti. She has also been part of Karn Sangini opposite Aashim Gulati.
She has also participated in Colors TV's Fear Factor: Khatron Ke Khiladi 10. Apart from this the actress also owns an expensive car. She is a proud owner of the Red color Hyundai i-20 car.

The Hyundai i20 starts at Rs 6.79 lakh (ex-showroom) and goes up to Rs 11.17 lakh (ex-showroom). The petrol variant ranges between Rs 6.79 lakh - Rs 9.69 lakh (ex-showroom). The diesel variant ranges between Rs 8.19 lakh - Rs 10.59 lakh (ex-showroom).

title: ‘Aquaman 2,’ ‘Flash’ Delayed to 2023; ‘Shazam 2’ Moves to Christmas 2022 in Warner Bros. Release Date Shuffle
excerpt: Warner Bros. has shuffled the release dates for several movies, including “Black Adam,” “The Flash,” “Aquaman 2,” “Wonka” and “Shazam 2.”

content.text:
Warner Bros. has shuffled the release dates for several movies, including “
Black Adam
,” “
The Flash
,” “
Aquaman 2
,” “Wonka” and “Shazam 2.”
“Aquaman and the Lost Kingdom” and “The Flash” are both being pushed from 2022 to 2023 due to COVID-induced production delays with visual effects. The Jason Momoa-starring sequel is being pushed back from Dec. 16, 2022, to March 17, 2023. Meanwhile, Ezra Miller’s first solo outing as Flash is speeding away from Nov. 4, 2022, to June 23, 2023.
Dwayne Johnson’s “Black Adam” is being pushed back three months to Oct. 21, 2022, and “
DC League of Super-Pets
” is moving to July 29, 2022, which was “Black Adam’s” original date. “Super-Pets,” in which Johnson voices Superman’s canine best friend, Krypto the Super-Dog, was previously dated for May 20, 2022.
1501674543521353728
“Shazam! Fury of the Gods” is the only movie to move up a few months. The Zachary Levi-starring pic is flying up from June 2, 2023, to Dec. 12, 2022, just in time for the Christmas season.


“We’re thrilled to bring ‘Shazam! Fury of the Gods’ to audiences as a Christmas gift this year,” said Jeff Goldstein, Warner Bros. president of domestic distribution. “Families of all ages will really enjoy it.”
In non-superhero release moves, Timothee Chalamet’s turn as chocolatier Willy Wonka in the origin story “Wonka” is being pushed back several months from March 17, 2023, to Dec. 15, 2023.
Finally, the shark disaster movie “Meg 2: The Trench,” starring Jason Statham, swims into theaters on Aug. 4, 2023.
Johnson was the first to rock the Warner Bros. release calendar, announcing on Wednesday afternoon that “Black Adam” and “Super-Pets” were being delayed. Warner Bros. then made the rest of the release changes official shortly after.


1501655951052578820
Warner Bros. is coming off of a 
hot start to 2022 with DC Comics’ “The Batman,”
 starring Robert Pattinson, Zoe Kravitz, Paul Dano, Colin Farrell and Jeffrey Wright. Director Matt Reeves’ take on the Caped Crusader brought in $134 million at the domestic box office in its opening weekend, which is the best debut of 2022 and the second-highest launch of the pandemic era, behind “Spider-Man: No Way Home.”
1501658383283363840
1501658807633649669
1501655223864942593

title: Pokemon Go Sierra counters January 2022: Best Pokemon to use & weaknesses
excerpt: Beating Team Go Rocket Leader Sierra in Pokemon Go will take skill, so we’ve put together

content.text:
Beating Team Go Rocket Leader Sierra in 
Pokemon
 Go will take skill, so we’ve put together the best counters and weakness tips to lead you straight to victory against the likes of Poliwag, Exeggutor, and Houndoom in January 2022.
In Pokemon Go, Trainers can collect Mysterious Components by defeating 
Team Go Rocket Grunts
 at invaded Pokestops within 
the game
. Once you have six of them, you’ll be able to form a Rocket Radar, which then leads you straight to the Team Go Rocket Leaders.
Unlike the 
Grunts
, who can be taken down fairly easily, trainers will have a difficult fight ahead of them when it comes to Team Go Rocket’s Leaders. There are four in total: 
Cliff
, 
Arlo
, 
Giovanni
, and Sierra, and all of them have unique ‘mon to battle with.
This guide will focus on taking down Sierra, including her current lineup in January 2022 and the best counters to defeat her in no time at all.
Additional reporting by 
Daniel Megarry
.


Sierra Pokemon Go counters (January 2022)
Sierra has always been a difficult opponent to take down in Pokemon Go, and that’s no different in January 2022, where her lineup has changed once again as part of the 
Power Plant event
.
At the start of every match, Sierra 
will always send out Poliwag.
 While Sierra’s lineup changes over time, these are the Pokemon she can use in January:
Phase 1: 
Poliwag
Phase 2: 
Exeggutor / Lapras / Sharpedo
Phase 3: 
Houndoom / Shiftry / Swampert

To defeat Sierra in Pokemon Go, you’ll need to utilize a variety of different types to counter her. We’ve featured a mix of stronger 
Legendaries
 and more common alternatives, so there should be something here to meet every Trainer’s needs, and all of them are solid choices.

title: Tejasswi Prakash Clarifies Krish Is Family Friend & Yogita Is NOT Karan's GF; Reveals If Marriage Is On Cards
excerpt: Tejasswi Prakash Clarifies Krish Is Family Friend & Yogita Is NOT Karan's GF; Reveals If Marriage Is On Cards

content.text:
Tejasswi Prakash has been in the limelight ever since she entered Bigg Boss 15. The Swaragini actress bagged Bigg Boss 15, which also became talk of the town- as many celebrated her victory and congratulated her and some trolled her as they felt Pratik Sehajpal deserved to win. Also, the actress has been in the news for her love angle with her co-contestant Karan Kundrra.
Recently, while talking to the Times Of India, Tejasswi clarified about a lot of things- from rumours of her dating Krish Khedekar, about Yogita Bihani being Karan Kundrra's girlfriend to Karan's cryptic post and their wedding. Take a look!


Tejasswi On Krish & Yogita
About Krish and Yogita the actress said, "Oh God, Krish is not my boyfriend and neither is Yogita Karan's girlfriend. She is a very sweet girl. Krish and I are family friends and have known each other since childhood."


Is Wedding On Cards?
Recently, Karan's father said that they will get Karan and Tejasswi married soon. Also, in the show, Karan had spoken about an astrologer, who said that he would settle down by March this year. When asked if marriage is on cards, she said, "It's not his plan. A pandit told him something. I don't know what the scene is, but I always took it as a joke. We have just come out of the house, and there is so much to talk about.
Tejasswi Says She & Karan Are Possessive
Tejasswi said that she is very possessive and she is proud of it. She added that she and Karan are 'shamelessly possessive,' and Karan too will agree with this. She said that they don't have any issue with it, nor should anybody else have!

title: Marvel's Avengers Fans Shocked by New Infinity War Surprise
excerpt: Marvel's Avengers on Google Stadia, PC, PS4, PS5, Xbox One, Xbox Series S, and Xbox Series X is getting a special Infinity War surprise today, courtesy of the in-game marketplace and courtesy of Iron Man.

content.text:
Marvel's Avengers\n on Google Stadia, PC, PS4, PS5, Xbox One, Xbox Series S, and Xbox Series X is getting a special \nInfinity War\n
 surprise today, courtesy of the in-game marketplace and courtesy of 
Iron Man. Hardcore Marvel fans will need no introduction to Iron Man's 
Mark 50, also known as The Mark L. This is one of Iron Man's more iconic
 suits as it's adorned by Tony Stark in \nAvengers: Infinity War\n 
in the battle against Thanos. In official lore, this is one of the more 
advanced Iron Man suits, possessing functions and capabilities that 
previous suits did not offer. In \nMarvel's Avengers\n though, none of this is going to be realized. Rather, it will simply be a cosmetic design. \nSurprisingly,
 the suit isn't in the game already, but today that is changing. 
Unfortunately, the only way to access it is to buy it via the in-game 
marketplace. In other words, there's no way to obtain by playing; you 
have to pay.\n"He's not a fan of having moons thrown at him," reads
 an official blurb about the suit. "Inspired by the Marvel Cinematic 
Universe, Iron Man's Marvel Studios' Avengers: Infinity War Outfit shows
 a man facing off against the harbingers of cosmic cataclysm."\n1511788537816891393\nAs you would expect, players are excited to finally get their hands 
on the Iron Man suit, and they are particularly excited about the 
faithful recreation of the suit. Many previous MCU suits have come under
 scrutiny from players for not being 100 percent faithful for various 
reasons. Thankfully for Iron Man fans, this isn't a problem with the 
Mark 50.\n1511792062194139143\n1511788537816891393\n1511788537816891393\nThere's no information on how much this suit will cost, but it will 
presumably be in line with previous MCU skins, which is to say, players 
should be prepared to pay a premium. \nMarvel's Avengers\n is available via Google Stadia, PC, PS4, 
PS5, Xbox One, Xbox Series S, and Xbox Series X. It's currently also 
accessible via Xbox Game Pass.\nAs always, feel free to share your thoughts and hot-takes in the comments section or, alternatively, hit me up on Twitter \n@Tyler_Fischer_ \nand let me know over there. What do you think of the Mark 50 being added to \nMarvel's Avengers\n? Will you be picking it up?\n

title: Ironheart Trailer Breakdown: 5 Shocking Reasons Riri Williams Is the MCU’s Next Iconic Hero
excerpt: Ironheart Trailer Breakdown: 5 Shocking Reasons Riri Williams Is the MCU’s Next Iconic Hero. Dive into the explosive trailer, uncover hidden details, and see why Riri Williams is set to redefine Marvel’s Phase 5.

content.text:
Ironheart Trailer Breakdown: 5 Shocking Reasons Riri Williams Is the MCU’s Next Iconic Hero. Dive into the explosive trailer, uncover hidden details, and see why Riri Williams is set to redefine Marvel's Phase 5.
Marvel Studios has officially released the trailer for its long-awaited Disney Plus series 
Ironheart
, introducing Riri Williams as a new tech-savvy hero in the MCU.  Set to premiere on June 24, 2025, on Disney+, the series promises to blend cutting-edge technology with street-level grit and a dash of magic. 
1922638025785250087
Trailer Breakdown: 5 Key Moments You Missed
The 
Ironheart
 trailer wastes no time establishing Riri Williams as Tony Stark’s spiritual successor—but with her own rebellious flair. Let’s dissect the highlights:
1. “Worst Job Interview Ever”
The trailer opens with Riri trapped in a Saw-esque elevator rigged by Anthony Ramos’ Parker Robbins (aka The Hood). With three minutes to escape, she MacGyvers a solution using a paperclip and sheer brainpower. 
“I need to be undeniable,”
 she declares.
2. Suit Up, Chicago-Style
Unlike Tony’s sleek Malibu labs, Riri builds her armor in a gritty Chicago garage. The trailer showcases her Mark II suit—a scrappier, more personalized upgrade from her 
Wakanda Forever
 prototype.

3. Magic vs. Tech Showdown
The Hood’s mystical powers clash with Riri’s engineering genius. One scene teases a neon-lit battle where energy blasts ricochet off her armor.
4. N.A.T.A.L.I.E. AI Debut
Comic fans spotted Riri’s AI companion (voiced by a surprise star?) in a blink-and-miss-it shot of her helmet HUD.
5. Alden Ehrenreich’s Mystery Role
The 
Solo
 alum appears as a shady tech dealer, hinting at a possible link to Justin Hammer or the Ten Rings.
Who Is Riri Williams? From Comics to MCU
Created by Brian Michael Bendis in 2016, Riri Williams is one of Marvel’s most beloved new heroes. Here’s how her journey translates to the MCU:
Comic Origins
: Orphaned teen prodigy reverse-engineers Tony’s armor at MIT.
MCU Tweaks
:
Post-
Wakanda Forever
 Timeline
: The series picks up after her clash with Namor.
Chicago Roots
: Expect deep dives into her family life and community ties.
Tony’s Shadow
: Trailer nods to Stark’s legacy (“I want to be iconic—*not just another cog”).
Villain Spotlight: The Hood’s Magic Threat
Anthony Ramos’ Parker Robbins isn’t your average tech bro villain. Here’s why The Hood is a game-changer:
Comic Backstory
: A small-time crook who gains demonic powers via a mystical cloak.
Trailer Clues
:
Recruits Riri for a heist gone wrong.
Wields chaotic energy blasts and teleportation.
His gang includes Zoe Terakes’ cyber-enhanced enforcer.
MCU Future
: Could bridge street-level crime and supernatural threats (Blade, anyone?).
Cast & Crew: Behind the Scenes
Ironheart
 boasts a powerhouse team both on and off-screen:
Dominique Thorne
 (Riri Williams): 
“She’s not the next Iron Man—she’s the first Ironheart.”
Anthony Ramos
 (The Hood): Brings charm and menace to the magic-wielding antagonist.
Ryan Coogler
 (EP): After 
Black Panther
’s success, he’s shaping Riri’s street-smart vibe.
Chinaka Hodge
 (Showrunner): Poet and 
Snowpiercer
 writer ensures emotional depth.
Alden Ehrenreich
: Plays a morally gray supplier with ties to Stark’s old rivals.
Fan Reactions: Hype vs. Skepticism
The trailer sparked fiery debates online. Here’s the split:
🔥 Hype Train
“Riri’s suit looks INCREDIBLE. Coogler never misses!”
 – @MCUTracker
“Finally, a hero who’s as smart as Shuri but with Chicago swagger.”
 – @ComixNerd
🤨 Skeptical Takes
“The Hood’s costume looks like a Hot Topic clearance rack.”
 – @CapeCritic
“Hope this isn’t another Secret Invasion letdown…”
 – @MarvelStans

What to Expect: 3 Predictions
Stark Tech Easter Eggs
: Watch for nods to Pepper Potts, Rescue, or even a surprise AI cameo.
Young Avengers Setup
: Riri could join Ms. Marvel and Kate Bishop in Phase 6.
Magic Unleashed
: The Hood’s cloak may tie to Doctor Strange’s multiverse chaos.
Release Details
Premiere Date
: June 24, 2025 (3 episodes)
Where to Watch
: Disney+ (JioHotstar in India)
Episodes
: 6 total, weekly drops after the premiere.
Why Ironheart Matters
Marvel’s Phase 5 needs a win, and Riri Williams’ grounded, tech-driven story could be the key. With Coogler’s vision, Thorne’s charisma, and a fresh take on heroism, 
Ironheart
 isn’t just another origin story—it’s a blueprint for the MCU’s future.
FAQs
Q1: When is 
Ironheart
 releasing?


A1:
 
Ironheart
 is set to premiere on June 24, 2025, with the first three episodes dropping on Disney+. 
Q2: Who is playing Riri Williams?


A2:
 Dominique Thorne portrays Riri Williams, reprising her role from 
Black Panther: Wakanda Forever
. 
Q3: Who is the main villain in 
Ironheart
?


A3:
 Anthony Ramos plays Parker Robbins, also known as The Hood, a character who brings a magical threat to Riri's tech-based world. 
Q4: Is 
Ironheart
 connected to Iron Man?


A4:
 While Riri Williams is inspired by Tony Stark, 
Ironheart
 focuses on her journey to forge her own identity as a hero, rather than directly continuing Iron Man's legacy. 
Q5: Will there be any cameos from other Marvel characters?


A5:
 While not confirmed, there are rumors of surprise cameos, potentially tying 
Ironheart
 to other parts of the MCU. 
Q6: Why was 
Ironheart
 delayed?


A6:
 The series was delayed as part of Marvel Studios' strategy to spread out Disney+ content more effectively, ensuring quality over quantity. 
Conclusion
Ironheart
 promises to be a thrilling addition to the Marvel Cinematic Universe, introducing a fresh hero who blends intellect, innovation, and heart. As Riri Williams steps into the spotlight, fans can look forward to a series that not only pays homage to Iron Man's legacy but also charts a bold new path for the future of the MCU.
Explore More:

The Forgotten Marvel Hero: Is Harley Keener the Next Iron Man?


Ironheart Release Delayed to 2025: What This Means for the MCU

title: Google's AI Conquers Classic Game: A Milestone in AI Gaming
excerpt: Google's AI model, Gemini 2.5 Pro, has conquered the classic game Pokémon Blue, marking a significant milestone in AI gaming. CEO Sundar Pichai celebrated this achievement, showcasing the progress of Google's AI technology and its potential in gaming and beyond.

content.text:
Google's AI Conquers Classic Game: A Milestone in AI Gaming
Imagine an AI so advanced it can navigate the pixelated world of a 29-year-old video game, making decisions, solving puzzles, and ultimately emerging victorious. That’s exactly what Google’s Gemini 2.5 Pro has achieved by completing the classic GameBoy game Pokémon Blue. This isn’t just a nostalgic trip down memory lane—it’s a groundbreaking moment in the evolution of artificial intelligence, blending cutting-edge tech with a beloved retro challenge.
1913464625393524967
1918455766542930004
A Celebratory Announcement
The big news came straight from the top: Google CEO Sundar Pichai couldn’t hide his excitement, announcing the feat on X with a shoutout that’s got the tech world buzzing. “What a finish! Gemini 2.5 Pro just completed Pokémon Blue!” he posted, giving a nod to software engineer Joel Z for masterminding the livestream that brought this achievement to life. Dubbed Gemini Plays Pokémon, the stream let fans watch in real-time as the AI tackled gym battles and captured Pokémon, proving its chops in a way that’s both geeky and genius.
Pichai’s enthusiasm wasn’t a solo act—Google execs have been cheering this project on from the sidelines, spotlighting Gemini’s edge in the AI race. It’s a win that’s as much about bragging rights as it is about innovation.
The Broader AI Landscape
This isn’t just Google flexing its tech muscles in a vacuum. The AI world is buzzing with competition, and Pokémon has unexpectedly become a battleground for showcasing brainpower. Over at Anthropic, their Claude AI has been grinding away at Pokémon Red—the sibling game to Blue—as part of a similar challenge kicked off earlier this year. Google’s not alone in this pixelated quest, and that’s what makes it juicy.
Logan Kilpatrick, product lead for Google AI Studio, has been dropping updates like breadcrumbs, noting last month that Gemini had snagged its fifth gym badge. That’s not just progress—it’s a subtle jab at the competition, hinting that Gemini’s pulling ahead in this unofficial AI showdown. Whether it’s Red or Blue, these games are proving to be more than child’s play; they’re a test of how well AI can handle complex, dynamic tasks.
1918455766542930004
Behind the Scenes: How Gemini Plays
So, how does an AI even play a video game? It’s not like Gemini’s got a GameBoy and a comfy couch. Instead, it relies on a slick setup called an “agent harness.” This tech processes screenshots of Pokémon Blue—complete with overlaid data—and lets the AI analyze what’s happening on screen. From there, it decides its next move, whether that’s battling a wild Pidgey or navigating a tricky gym puzzle. It’s like giving the AI a pair of eyes and a brain to match, all wrapped up in code.
Joel Z, the 30-year-old software engineer behind the livestream, has been the human touch in this high-tech tale. He’s admitted to stepping in with minor tweaks—like clarifying a confusing game mechanic involving a Rocket Grunt—to sharpen Gemini’s reasoning. But he’s quick to clarify: no cheating, no spoilers, just a little nudge to keep things on track. It’s a partnership where the AI does the heavy lifting, and Joel plays coach.
Challenges and the Road Ahead
Even with this victory, Joel Z keeps it real: “Gemini Plays Pokémon is a work in progress.” There are still bugs to squash and upgrades to roll out. Meanwhile, Anthropic’s Claude hasn’t crossed the finish line in Pokémon Red, leaving Gemini’s win as the standout moment in this AI gaming saga. It’s a milestone, sure, but it’s also a teaser for what’s next.
This achievement sparks some big questions. If an AI can master a game like Pokémon Blue—with its mix of strategy, exploration, and decision-making—what else could it conquer? Could we see AI tackling real-world challenges with the same finesse? The possibilities are as endless as a Pokémon trainer’s journey.
1918694207176188386
Conclusion: A New Chapter in AI
Google’s Gemini 2.5 Pro hasn’t just beaten a classic game; it’s cracked open a door to a future where AI can take on tasks we’ve only dreamed of. For gamers, it’s a cool nod to a ’90s icon. For tech fans, it’s a glimpse at where artificial intelligence is headed. And for the curious? It’s a story that’s just too fun to ignore.
Want to dive deeper into the AI revolution? Check out our AI news section (/ml) for more updates that’ll keep you in the loop. The game’s not over—it’s only just begun.

title: Issue Pairing Sony Bluetooth Wireless Headphones With Another Device
excerpt: Struggling to connect your Sony Bluetooth wireless headphones to a new phone, laptop, or tablet? This step-by-step guide explains how to put Sony headphones into pairing mode, handle passcode prompts, and fix common Bluetooth connection issues across devices.

content.text:
Issue Pairing (Connecting) Sony Bluetooth Wireless Headphones to Another Device
If your Sony Bluetooth wireless headphones won’t connect to another device (phone, tablet, computer, etc.), follow the simplified steps below to enter pairing mode and establish a Bluetooth connection.
Before You Start
✔ Place both devices within 
1 meter (3 ft)
 of each other. (
Help Guide
)
✔ Make sure both have enough battery — low power can prevent pairing. (
Sony India
)
✔ If the headphones were paired with another device previously, turn off that device’s Bluetooth or 
“Forget” the headphones
 from its Bluetooth list. (
Sony India
)
How to Pair Sony Bluetooth Headphones
1. Enter Bluetooth Pairing Mode
Most Sony Bluetooth headphones enter pairing mode automatically the 
first time
 you turn them on. For a new connection (second device or after previously paired devices):
Turn off
 your headphones if currently on.
Press and 
hold the Power button
 for 
about 5–7 seconds
 until the indicator light flashes rapidly (or you hear voice guidance saying “Bluetooth pairing”).
On some models, the Bluetooth indicator will blink rapidly when in pairing mode. (
Sony UK
)
On truly wireless earbuds (WF series), put them in your ears and 
hold the touch sensors
 on both units to start pairing mode. (
Sony
)
2. Activate Bluetooth on Your Device
Go to 
Settings → Bluetooth
 on the device you want to connect (phone, tablet, laptop, etc.).
Make sure Bluetooth is turned 
ON
.
Look for your Sony headphones in the list of available devices and tap to connect. (
Sony UK
)
3. Complete the Pairing
Select the Sony headphone model name from the Bluetooth list.
Some devices may ask for a Bluetooth 
passcode
 — if so, enter 
0000
. (
Help Guide
)
Wait for the connection confirmation (indicator light may turn solid or you’ll hear a confirmation tone). (
Sony UK
)
Notes & Troubleshooting
If Pairing Fails
✔ 
Restart both devices
 and try again. (
Sony India
)
✔ 
Delete old Bluetooth pairings
 on your phone or computer and reconnect. (
Sony India
)
✔ Bring the devices closer together (within 1 m). (
Help Guide
)
✔ Make sure the headphones aren’t already connected to another device. (
Sony India
)
Additional Tips
Some Sony models support 
multipoint connectivity
 (connect to two devices simultaneously) — check your manual or 
Sony | Headphones Connect
 app for support and switching devices. (
Sony
)
If the headphone’s Bluetooth settings still don’t show up, you may need to 
reset or initialize the headphones
 — this clears all saved pairing data. (
Sony India
)
Summary
Enter pairing mode
 on your Sony headphones (long-press Power or Bluetooth button).
Enable Bluetooth
 on the target device.
Select the headphone model
 from the Bluetooth list.
Enter passcode 0000
 if prompted.
Once connected successfully, your Sony headphones will remember the device and reconnect automatically in the future. (
Sony UK
)

title: Flutter in 2026: Strategy, Roadmap, and the State of the Ecosystem
excerpt: Flutter has evolved from a cross-platform experiment into a mature UI framework powering mobile, web, desktop, and embedded products at scale. This deep-dive examines Flutter’s 2026 strategy, core engineering priorities, and how Google’s roadmap intersects with a rapidly expanding open-source ecosystem.

content.text:
Each year, the Flutter project goes through a structured planning process to reassess its priorities, technical direction, and long-term role within Google and the wider developer ecosystem. While such strategy documents are often kept private inside large technology organizations, Flutter continues to take a different approach.
As an open-source framework with a rapidly growing global user base, Flutter’s success depends on clarity and trust. Making its strategic thinking public helps developers, enterprises, and platform partners understand where the framework is heading—and how their own investments can align with it.
This updated overview reframes the original 2022 strategy in the context of Flutter’s reality in 2026: a mature, production-proven UI toolkit used across mobile, web, desktop, and embedded platforms.
Flutter’s Core Mission in 2026
Flutter’s mission remains fundamentally unchanged, but its scope has expanded.
Flutter exists to enable developers to build high-quality, performant user interfaces from a single codebase, across multiple platforms, without sacrificing control, expressiveness, or performance.
By 2026, Flutter is no longer positioned as an “alternative” framework. It is now a mainstream choice for:
Consumer mobile applications
Enterprise internal tools
Desktop productivity software
Embedded and automotive interfaces
The strategy has shifted from rapid expansion to 
stability, scalability, and ecosystem maturity
.
Strategic Principles Guiding Flutter Development
Flutter’s roadmap is shaped by a small set of guiding principles that influence engineering trade-offs and prioritization.
Key Principles
Performance as a baseline, not a feature

Smooth animations, predictable frame times, and low-latency input handling remain non-negotiable.
Platform respect, not platform imitation

Flutter aims to integrate naturally with each operating system rather than abstract them away completely.
Open ecosystem over centralized control

The framework is designed to enable external innovation rather than constrain it.
Long-term API stability

Breaking changes are minimized to protect large production applications.
Major Focus Areas Through 2026
Flutter’s investments over the last several years can be grouped into a few clear strategic pillars.
Platform Maturity and Parity
Flutter’s early years focused heavily on mobile. By 2026, the emphasis has shifted to ensuring that all supported platforms are first-class citizens.
Current platform priorities
Platform
Strategic Focus
Android & iOS
Performance consistency, tooling stability, OS feature parity
Web
Reduced bundle size, faster startup, better SEO integration
Windows
Native-feeling desktop UX, input and window management
macOS
Platform conventions, accessibility, system integrations
Linux
Embedded systems, custom shells, industrial applications
Embedded
Automotive, kiosks, smart displays
Tooling, Productivity, and Developer Experience

https://www.instagram.com/p/DST2_XaFq-a/

As Flutter adoption has grown inside enterprises, tooling reliability has become as important as framework features.
Key investments include:
Faster incremental builds and hot reload stability
Improved debugging and profiling for large codebases
Better DevTools support for memory, jank, and rendering analysis
Stronger IDE integrations for long-running projects
Developer experience priorities
Area
Focus
Build systems
Predictability and speed
Debugging
Deep insight without complexity
Refactoring
Safer large-scale changes
CI/CD
Deterministic builds across platforms
Rendering, Graphics, and Engine Evolution
Flutter’s custom rendering engine remains one of its defining characteristics. Through 2026, work continues to ensure it scales with modern hardware.
Notable areas of emphasis include:
Continued evolution of Impeller for more predictable rendering
Better GPU utilization across platforms
Reduced jank under heavy UI load
Improved text, accessibility, and internationalization rendering
Rather than chasing experimental features, engine work prioritizes 
consistency and predictability
.
The Role of Google vs the Open-Source Community
A critical clarification remains necessary when discussing Flutter’s strategy.
When the strategy refers to “we,” it reflects 
Google’s investment decisions
, not ownership of the project as a whole.
Flutter is built and maintained by a broad coalition:
Individual developers contributing packages and fixes
Large companies integrating Flutter into products
Platform vendors extending Flutter to new environments
Major Ecosystem Contributors
Contributor Type
Examples of Impact
OS vendors
Platform ports and integrations
Automotive companies
Embedded UI and infotainment systems
Consumer tech firms
Performance improvements at scale
Open-source maintainers
Packages, plugins, tooling
Many important initiatives—such as automotive deployments, embedded Linux work, or custom platform ports—exist outside Google’s direct roadmap but are fully part of the Flutter ecosystem.
What the Strategy Does 
Not
 Promise
It is important to interpret Flutter’s published strategy correctly.
It is 
not a binding commitment
It does 
not limit external contributions
It will evolve as technology and priorities change
The document reflects current intent, not contractual guarantees. This flexibility allows Flutter to adapt without locking the ecosystem into rigid plans.
Flutter’s Position Heading Beyond 2026
By 2026, Flutter has moved from rapid expansion to long-term consolidation. The focus is no longer about proving viability, but about ensuring durability.
The strategy emphasizes:
Sustainable performance improvements
Enterprise-grade tooling and stability
Healthy decentralization of innovation
Clear but flexible technical direction
Rather than chasing trends, Flutter’s roadmap reflects a framework settling into its role as long-term infrastructure for cross-platform user interfaces—shaped by Google’s investment, but ultimately defined by its global community.

title: The Stranger Things Finale Explained: A Messy, Emotional, and Divisive Goodbye
excerpt: After nine years, Stranger Things ends with a finale that is emotionally generous but structurally uneven. The Season 5 conclusion delivers heartfelt goodbyes and heavy nostalgia, yet struggles with safe storytelling, unresolved mysteries, and diluted stakes. This review breaks down why the ending satisfied fans, frustrated critics, and ultimately closed one of Netflix’s most defining series on conflicted terms.

content.text:
It is hard to overstate the cultural footprint of 
Stranger Things
. Since its debut in 2016, the Duffer Brothers’ retro sci-fi drama has been more than a television series—it has been a cultural event. It revived Kate Bush’s chart presence, brought 
Dungeons & Dragons
 into the mainstream, and became a cornerstone of Netflix’s rise as a dominant streaming platform.
But as any long-running story proves, endings are harder than beginnings.
After a nine-year run, the party has finally disbanded. The Season 5 finale—released as a two-hour, movie-length event on New Year’s Eve—marks the end of the journey. The result is the most uneven chapter the series has ever delivered: ambitious, emotionally loaded, and deeply divisive.
The finale is pulled between two competing goals. On one hand, it wants to be a blockbuster spectacle worthy of its scale. On the other, it is determined to send every major character off with warmth and reassurance. What emerges is a conclusion that is messy, awkward, and overextended—yet, for long-time fans, still strangely satisfying.
The Structure: A Game of Two Halves

https://www.instagram.com/p/DMGzTaOPZEx/


https://www.instagram.com/p/DTD9J8lkgtB/

The finale is clearly divided into two distinct experiences.
The first half focuses on the climactic confrontation with Vecna and the Mind Flayer, leaning heavily on visual effects and escalating stakes. The second half slows to a crawl, spending nearly an hour on an expansive epilogue designed to resolve as many character arcs as possible.
This structure exposes the show’s biggest problem at the finish line: narrative congestion. With a cast that has grown steadily over five seasons and stakes inflated to near-apocalyptic levels, the finale often feels overcrowded. Key moments rely on characters explaining the plot rather than letting events unfold organically. Instead of tension building through action, exposition frequently does the heavy lifting.
The Battle: Spectacle Versus Substance
2007678405156725063
The final confrontation is where criticism has been sharpest. While visually ambitious, the battle lacks the tactical creativity that once defined the series.
Eleven and Will face Vecna in a psychic showdown, while the rest of the Hawkins group confronts the Mind Flayer in the physical world. The problem is one of scale and internal logic. The Mind Flayer—previously framed as a cosmic, near-unstoppable force—ends up restrained by teenagers armed with flares, slingshots, and improvised weapons.
This imbalance raises uncomfortable questions. If the Mind Flayer is the ultimate threat, why does it appear more vulnerable than its own foot soldiers? The sense of danger that once made the Upside Down frightening is diluted by how easily the monster is neutralized.
Vecna’s defeat also feels abrupt. After multiple seasons establishing him as an almost omnipotent antagonist, his downfall seems designed less as a strategic victory and more as an excuse for a cinematic hero moment—particularly for Joyce—rather than a payoff earned through careful planning and consequence.
The Emotional Core: Where the Show Still Works

Where the finale falters mechanically, it succeeds emotionally.
When the dust settles, 
Stranger Things
 remembers what has always been its greatest strength: character relationships. The performances from the ensemble cast elevate material that might otherwise feel indulgent.
Natalia Dyer, Gaten Matarazzo, Finn Wolfhard, and Maya Hawke deliver some of the most grounded work of the series, conveying exhaustion, relief, and unresolved trauma. These characters have been fighting supernatural threats since childhood, and the finale gives them space—sometimes too much space—to reflect on what that cost them.
Even when the plotting strains credibility, the emotional sincerity lands.
The Epilogue: Closure or Overindulgence?
The extended epilogue makes a clear creative choice: emotions over answers.
An 18-month time jump shows where the survivors end up after Hawkins begins to heal:
Hopper and Joyce finally become engaged.
Nancy pursues journalism, while Jonathan turns toward film studies.
Steve Harrington becomes a high school coach, a fitting evolution for the show’s most reliable protector.
Max, despite spending much of the previous two years in a coma, somehow graduates with her class—a moment that tested plausibility for many viewers.
For dedicated fans, this epilogue feels like a necessary exhale after years of escalating trauma. For others, it feels indulgent, a refusal to let the story end without reassuring everyone involved.
The Backlash: Ratings, Review Bombing, and “The Bridge”
The finale’s reception reflects its internal contradictions.
Season 5 holds the lowest audience score in the show’s history on Rotten Tomatoes, sitting far below its critical rating. Much of the online backlash has been traced to Episode 7, “The Bridge,” in which Will Byers comes out as gay to his friends.
The scene, positioned as a moment of self-acceptance and emotional defiance against Vecna, became the target of review-bombing campaigns rooted in homophobic backlash. The controversy has overshadowed more substantive criticisms related to pacing, stakes, and unresolved storylines.
Ross Duffer defended the scene as a long-planned narrative payoff, emphasizing its importance both thematically and for Noah Schnapp’s character arc. The intensity of the reaction highlights how cultural flashpoints can distort broader discussion of a show’s actual strengths and weaknesses.
Playing It Safe: The Cost of Avoiding Consequences
Perhaps the most consistent critique of the finale is its unwillingness to commit to loss.
Major characters survive situations that previously would have carried fatal consequences. The military—once portrayed as ruthless and dangerous—suddenly becomes ineffective, allowing characters involved in lethal confrontations to walk away without interrogation or consequence.
Eleven’s apparent sacrifice is the clearest example. Her presumed death is framed as the ultimate emotional climax, only to be immediately softened by dialogue suggesting she may have survived and gone into hiding. The ambiguity attempts to satisfy both tragedy and optimism, but instead leaves the moment feeling calculated.
Rather than a bold ending, it comes across as cautious storytelling.
Unanswered Questions the Finale Leaves Behind
For a series built on mystery, the finale leaves an unusual number of loose threads:
Dr. Owens:
 Last seen imprisoned, his fate is never addressed.
The pregnant test subjects:
 Introduced as part of the Upside Down experiments, their outcomes remain unclear.
Upside Down physics:
 Previously established rules are quietly ignored, particularly around water and environmental consistency.
Henry Creel’s motivation:
 Vecna’s endgame remains vague, reducing him to a largely one-dimensional villain despite ample opportunity for complexity or internal conflict.
These omissions don’t break the story outright, but they leave the ending feeling incomplete in ways earlier seasons worked hard to avoid.
Final Verdict: 3.5/5
Stranger Things
 ends not with precision, but with feeling.
Season 5 is overloaded, structurally uneven, and often unwilling to commit to the consequences its own narrative demands. The climactic battle lacks the ingenuity that once made the show tense, and the “safe” resolution undercuts its dramatic weight.
Yet it is difficult to dismiss the finale outright. For viewers who have followed these characters for nearly a decade, the emotional closure lands. The goodbye feels earned, even if the path there is cluttered.
Stranger Things
 reshaped streaming television and left an indelible mark on pop culture. This finale may signal the end of its cultural dominance, but it closes the door gently—wrapped in nostalgia, sentiment, and affection. For many, that will be enough.
Quick Summary of the Finale
Action:
 Visually ambitious but strategically underwhelming.
Emotion:
 Strong performances and character moments carry the ending.
Plot:
 Marked by unanswered questions and cautious writing.
Villains:
 Vecna remains threatening but underdeveloped.
Legacy:
 A defining Netflix series that ends imperfectly, but with heart intact.
